unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Two-Sample $T$-Test
question_text: A two-sample $T$-test attempts to determine if

choices.text: A significant difference exists between two proportions.
A significant difference exists between two means when the population standard deviation is known.
A significant difference exists between two means when the population standard deviation is unknown.
A straight line relationship exists between two quantitative variables.
A relationship exists between two categorical variables.

solution:
A two-sample $T$-test should be performed to determine if a significant difference exists between two independent samples representing two populations.

Choice 'C' is correct; this by definition is the appropriate situation for a two sample T-test.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; a two-proportion $Z$-test would be appropriate for the situation in Choice 'A'. A 2-sample $T$ test would not be appropriate because proportions are not being studied.

Choice 'B is incorrect; the $T$ distribution does not assume the population standard deviation is known. Use the $Z$ distribution when the population standard deviation is assumed to be known.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; a linear regression $T$-test deals with bivariate data that has an explanatory/response relationship would be appropriate for this situation mentioned in Choice 'D'.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; a chi-squared test would be appropriate for the selection mentioned in Choice 'E' as it is used to test multiple proportions dealing with categorical variables.
